ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learnt so much about German grammar, vocabulary and culture. This class built really well from what we learned in L1, and presented new information in a way that was really engaging.
Basic conversational German skills including reading and writing.
It taught me basic skills in language skills; memorization, conceptual mapping, phonetics, and other skills useful to communication in German

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the asynchronous days were a huge strength. It allowed us more flexibility in terms of when we completed the work, and also in terms of how long we took to do it. I often used the asynchronous days to spend a long time looking up vocabulary and consolidating my understanding of new grammar topics. I think in future, it might be helpful to have vocabulary lists sent out for each unit, to make it easier to study for tests and also to make sure we have all of the necessary vocabulary before moving forwards.

I think the course is very fast-paced and intensive in a really good way (language courses need daily time devoted to it) but I think there could have been more explanatory instruction during the live/virtual days rather than leaving all the instruction to the asynchronous days.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As mentioned above, the asynchronous days were a huge asset to the course, and I don't think the department would have experimented with them had it not been for COVID-19. I'm hoping they stay in the fall.
Given it was online, I thought it was handled well. Very interactive

I think the asynchronous days were actually very helpful, but often the workload was too high. What was advertised as an amount of work that would take 50 minutes often took at least 2 hours and sometimes even 4 hours. I think short pop quizzes or in-class exercises where one could get instant feedback would be helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to develop their German skills. My experience of the German department so far, in L1 and now L2, has been amazing and I think the language is very well taught at Yale. I have walked away from this class genuinely able to communicate and understand a decent level of German, and I am excited to continue to learn the language.
Yes! My german skills really improved, BUT the student must be willing to put in the time and effort that is required of the course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Synchronous, seminar-format classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday, with asynchronous work set for Tuesday and Thursday.
asynchronous virtual work and synchronous virtual lectures

live virtual lectures MWF
Asynchronous work TR
Synchronous in person classes combined with asynchronous days of work.
